title: Short note: Regional Disparities (30/08/2019)
text:
Much have been said about the out-performance of the US stock market vs other markets worldwide. An accommodative Federal Reserve and recent corporate tax cuts have helped pushed this rally even further.

With all the hype around the US stock market, it feels odd that this region's 1 year return is basically flat. This of course after we've seen the big sell-off during December 2018, while the recent trade war talks between the US and China have also added to volatility.

MSCI USA

And how does the rest of the world compare?

It turns out not very well, especially Emerging Markets. The chart below shows the 12 month returns of the US (in blue), Developed Markets ex-US (in green) and Emerging Markets (in red).

Emerging Markets got spared during the sharp December 2018 sell-off, but trade war fears are weighing heavily on this region.

MSCI Regions

This flows chart explains it really well, as trade tensions heightened during August, investors dumped their Emerging Markets holdings, recording the largest monthly outflow since November 2016.

Source: IIF Twitter Account (@IIF)

The one part of Emerging Markets that investors still seem to adore is their debt. With negative yielding bonds in most of Europe and also Japan, investors have been rushing to Emerging Markets for yield. The Emerging Market bond index is at a 19 month high.

iShares JPM EMB

It's not just Emerging Market bonds offering superior yields, it's also Emerging Market equities (but as we've seen, investors aren't buying into this just yet).

Source: Topdown Charts Twitter account (@topdowncharts))

Record low yields, an accommodative Federal Reserve and trade war talks have been very beneficial for gold.

Gold Futures

In fact, there has been a really strong relationship between gold and negative yielding debt.

Source: IIF Twitter account (@IIF))

As it stands, the outcome of the trade war talks and the future "accommodativeness" of the Fed will likely dictate market movements in the short-term.
